metadata.purpose: Generate comprehensive, professional README documentation for DevOps projects
metadata.target_audience: Employers, technical recruiters, fellow developers reviewing portfolio projects

platform_context.role: Foundation and source of truth for all project documentation
platform_context.what_employers_see: README.md is the FIRST thing employers review. This is your project's first impression.
platform_context.key_insight: GitHub is NOT social media. It's a professional portfolio. Employers spend 30-60 seconds scanning your README. Make every section count.

vocabulary.use: Technical terminology, industry-standard terms, precise language
vocabulary.avoid: Slang, excessive emojis, casual language, marketing hype

examples.good: "Implemented Kubernetes cluster orchestration with automated scaling policies"
examples.bad: "Made a cool Kubernetes thing that auto-scales lol"

voice_characteristics.item: Explain WHY you chose technologies, not just WHAT you used
Use active voice and strong verbs

section.name: Project Title
section.purpose: Immediately communicate what the project is

tips.tip: Be specific about what the project does

section.name: Project Description (1-2 sentences)
section.purpose: Hook the reader with the core value proposition
section.example: A production-ready Kubernetes cluster deployed on AWS using Terraform and automated with CI/CD pipelines. This project demonstrates infrastructure-as-code best practices, security hardening, and scalable DevOps architecture.

tips.tip: Answer: What does it do? Why does it matter? What problem does it solve?

section.name: Table of Contents
section.condition: Only include if README is longer than 2000 words

section.name: Motivation / Why This Project
section.purpose: Explain your learning goals and project rationale
section.example: This project was built to master Kubernetes orchestration and infrastructure-as-code practices. The goal was to create a production-ready cluster that demonstrates: - Automated infrastructure provisioning with Terraform - Container orchestration best practices - Security hardening and RBAC implementation - CI/CD pipeline integration

tips.tip: Be honest about your learning goals

section.name: Architecture Diagram
section.format: ASCII diagram or link to image

tips.tip: Show data flow and component relationships
Use ASCII art or embed image

section.name: Prerequisites
section.purpose: List what's needed to run the project
section.example: - Docker 20.10+ - Kubernetes 1.24+ - Terraform 1.0+ - AWS CLI v2 - kubectl configured for cluster access

tips.tip: Link to installation guides if helpful

section.name: Installation / Setup Instructions
section.purpose: Step-by-step guide to get the project running
section.example:
## Installation
1. Clone the repository \`\`\`bash git clone https://github.com/username/project-name.git cd project-name \`\`\`
2. Configure AWS credentials \`\`\`bash aws configure \`\`\`
3. Initialize Terraform \`\`\`bash cd terraform/ terraform init \`\`\`
4. Deploy infrastructure \`\`\`bash terraform apply \`\`\`

tips.tip: Include all commands exactly as typed

section.name: Usage Examples
section.purpose: Show how to use the project
section.example:
## Usage
### Deploy an application \`\`\`bash kubectl apply -f deployments/app.yaml \`\`\`
### Check cluster status \`\`\`bash kubectl get nodes kubectl get pods --all-namespaces \`\`\`
### Scale deployment \`\`\`bash kubectl scale deployment app --replicas=3 \`\`\`

section.name: Project Structure
section.example: \`\`\` project-name/ ├── terraform/ │ ├── main.tf │ ├── variables.tf │ └── outputs.tf ├── kubernetes/ │ ├── deployments/ │ ├── services/ │ └── configmaps/ ├── scripts/ │ ├── deploy.sh │ └── cleanup.sh ├── docs/ │ ├── architecture.md │ └── troubleshooting.md └── README.md \`\`\`

section.name: Key Technologies
section.example: - **Kubernetes**: Container orchestration platform for managing containerized applications - **Terraform**: Infrastructure-as-code tool for provisioning AWS resources - **Docker**: Containerization for consistent deployment environments - **AWS**: Cloud provider for scalable infrastructure - **GitHub Actions**: CI/CD pipeline automation

tips.tip: Explain WHY each technology was chosen

section.name: Learning Outcomes
section.example:
## Learning Outcomes
✓ Mastered Kubernetes cluster architecture and node management ✓ Implemented infrastructure-as-code with Terraform ✓ Configured RBAC and security policies ✓ Set up automated CI/CD pipelines ✓ Troubleshot networking and storage issues ✓ Optimized resource allocation and cost

tips.tip: Be specific about what you learned

section.name: Challenges & Solutions
section.example:
## Challenges & Solutions
### Challenge 1: Pod Networking Issues **Problem**: Pods couldn't communicate across nodes **Solution**: Configured CNI plugin (Flannel) for inter-node communication **Learning**: Understanding network policies and CNI plugins
### Challenge 2: Persistent Storage **Problem**: Data lost when pods restarted **Solution**: Implemented EBS volumes and PersistentVolumeClaims **Learning**: Kubernetes storage architecture and StatefulSets

section.name: Future Improvements
section.example:
## Future Improvements
- [ ] Implement service mesh (Istio) for advanced traffic management - [ ] Add monitoring and alerting (Prometheus + Grafana) - [ ] Implement GitOps workflow with ArgoCD - [ ] Add multi-region failover - [ ] Implement cost optimization strategies

tips.tip: Show you're thinking beyond the current project
Demonstrate awareness of industry best practices

readability.item: Break up large blocks of text
Use code blocks for all code examples

accuracy.item: All code examples must be tested and working

completeness.item: Cover all major aspects of the project
Provide enough detail for someone to reproduce
Link to external resources where appropriate

success_metrics.metric: All code examples are tested and working

instructions_for_ai_agent.step1: Read the DevOps_Documentation_Framework.md file, specifically the "GitHub: Your Foundation" and "Comprehensive README Template" sections
instructions_for_ai_agent.step2: Understand that this README will be the FIRST thing employers see
instructions_for_ai_agent.step3: Generate content that is professional, detailed, and demonstrates expertise
instructions_for_ai_agent.step4: Include all sections listed in content_structure
instructions_for_ai_agent.step5: Use the tone_and_voice guidelines - professional, clear, authoritative
instructions_for_ai_agent.step6: Ensure all code examples are realistic and working
instructions_for_ai_agent.step7: Make the README scannable with clear headings and formatting
instructions_for_ai_agent.step8: Output as properly formatted Markdown (.md file)
instructions_for_ai_agent.step9: Include at least 2-3 challenges with solutions
instructions_for_ai_agent.step10: Proofread for spelling, grammar, and technical accuracy

input_variables.variable: One-sentence description of what the project does
Comma-separated list of technologies (e.g., Kubernetes, Terraform, AWS)
What you wanted to learn from this project

output_format.structure: Follow the content_structure sections in order
